head.title: U.S Shirked Role At Ozone Meeting

hedline.hl1: U.S Shirked Role At Ozone Meeting

block.p: Your Dec. 10 news article on the conclusion of the international meeting in Vienna where 149 countries met to amend the Montreal Protocol governing protection of the ozone layer did not convey the huge environmental disappointment over the weak results and the failure of United States leadership.

Your Dec. 10 news article on the conclusion of the international meeting in Vienna where 149 countries met to amend the Montreal Protocol governing protection of the ozone layer did not convey the huge environmental disappointment over the weak results and the failure of United States leadership.

Rather than retaining the United States deadline of the year 2001 for phasing out methyl bromide, the nations participating in the meeting agreed to only a 50 percent reduction by 2005, with a 2010 phase-out date for industrial countries. Methyl bromide, an agricultural pesticide, had been the only industrial chemical responsible for depleting the earth's protective ozone shield not previously designated for elimination.

This cave-in to agribusiness by the United States and several other countries such as France, Spain, Japan and Kenya leaves methyl bromide -- the soil-brutalizing, toxic chemical, which is very risky for farm workers -- in usage far too long, with increased usage likely in developing countries.
These cowardly decisions mean, according to the latest scientific assessment, that there will be millions of additional cases of skin cancer and eye cataracts worldwide.
Furthermore, they perpetuate the ozone depletion experiment with all of its health and ecosystem risks on our children and the life on our planet.
CORINNA GILFILLAN Washington, Dec. 11, 1995 The writer, ozone program director for Friends of the Earth, was an attendee at the Montreal Protocol meeting in Vienna.
